author: Daniel Milligan
title: David Cameron in North East LIVE: Updates from Prime Minister's EU visit at Hitachi Rail
text:
08:48 Daniel Milligan Brexit lead to jobs lost - Hitachi boss 
The chairman of Hitachi has issued a stark warning that the “cold economic reality of Brexit” would mean jobs being lost and investment being held bac k. 
The firm opened its £82m train manufacturing facility in Newton Aycliffe, County Durham, nine months ago as well as basing its global rail HQ in London, and chairman Hiroaki Nakanishi said the UK was attractive as the best base for accessing the European Union’s market of 500m consumers. 
However, Mr Nakanishi - in comments that were later picked up by Prime Minister David Cameron - said Brexit represented a “boulder on the line”. 
He warned of the impact of Brexit on Japanese investors: “In the ‘80s Nissan and Toyota came to the UK on the basis that if they produced here and employed a British workforce they would be treated as European companies. Hiroaki Nakanishi, CEO of Hitachi 
“This was only possible because Britain was inside the EU; and so the UK car industry was revived and became an exporter again. From Japan, this incredible success story looks like a huge gain from the UK’s membership of the EU. 
“We worry because those advocating Brexit have no answer to how the UK could negotiate cost-free access to this huge market from a position outside it. 
“It would take a long time and result in uncertain market conditions; during this renegotiation period, investors would probably be waiting to see the outcomes, hold back on investment, and jobs would be lost. This is the cold economic reality of Brexit.” 08:39 Daniel Milligan Brexit Hitachi warning from Cameron 
Hitachi’s warning that quitting the European Union could force it to rethink plans to invest in the North East is “incredibly powerful”, David Cameron has insisted. 
The Prime Minister echoed the comments in the House of Commons after Hitachi chairman Hiroaki Nakanishi said that a decision to leave the EU on June 23 made the case for future investment “very different”. PA Wire 
The huge multinational company is one of the region’s fastest-growing employers and will soon employ more than 700 people at its Newton Aycliffe manufacturing site, making new trains for the East Coast, Great Western and Scotrail lines. 
Mr Cameron, who is urging voters to support remaining in the EU, told the House of Commons that leaving would be bad for the economy of the North East. 
He said: “One of the reasons why international companies like Hitachi invest in Britain - of course we have excellent labour relations, the English language, a very hard working workforce, great engineers - but they also invest here because we are members of the single market. 
“And I thought what the head of Hitachi said this week about wanting us to be the European headquarters, to manufacture trains in the North East and sell them all over Europe, and how that might not be possible if we were to leave, was an incredibly powerful statement.” 
He added: “So in my clear view jobs come first, and if people want to vote for jobs they should vote for remain on June 23.” 08:30 Daniel Milligan Prime Minister at Hitachi Rail 
David Cameron will be in the North East on Thursday to push home his case for Britain remaining in the EU. 
The Prime Minister will visit Hitachi Rail in Newton Aycliffe, County Durham, to deliver a speech to workers ahead of June 23’s referendum. 
Speaking ahead of his visit, Mr Cameron warned a Brexit would mean firms such as the Japanese rail giant wouldn’t invest in the region. 
He echoed the comments in the House of Commons after Hitachi chairman Hiroaki Nakanishi said that a decision to leave the EU made the case for future investment “very different”. 
Mr Cameron, who is urging voters to support the remain campaign, said that leaving would be bad for the economy of the North East.
